chunk_summary.summary: Introduces the goal: use discrete-time models with very small intertick time to approximate continuous-time price dynamics. States that a simple discrete model with constant drift and noise approximates a log-normal distribution under both the real measure P and the martingale measure Q, and that this approach can be used (non-rigorously) to derive the Black–Scholes formula.

Presents the discrete model setup. Parameters: intertick time δt (to be taken to 0), volatility σ, stock growth rate μ, and riskless rate r. Cash bond B_t = exp(r t). Stock follows a recombinant multiplicative binomial tree: from current value s the next-step values are s·exp(μ δt ± σ√δt). Jumps are equally likely with p = 1/2.

Derives the multi-step expression for S_t after n = t/δt ticks: S_t = S_0 exp( μ t + σ √t (2 X_n − n)/√n ). Notes X_n ~ Binomial(n,1/2) with mean n/2 and variance n/4 so (2X_n − n)/√n has mean 0 and variance 1. By the Central Limit Theorem this term converges to N(0,1) as n→∞, hence log S_t converges to a normal distribution with mean log S_0 + μ t and variance σ^2 t, i.e., S_t becomes log-normal in the continuous limit.

key_definitions.definition: Length of one discrete time step. The continuous limit is obtained by letting δt → 0.
Scale of the random multiplicative shocks in each step; appears as ±σ√δt in one-step log-returns.
Deterministic component of one-step log-return, appears as μ δt per step.
Constant rate for the cash bond; B_t = exp(r t). (Introduced on page 2.)
Riskless asset evolving deterministically: B_t = exp(r t).
Number of discrete steps up to time t: n = t / δt.
Total number of up-jumps among n independent steps; X_n ~ Binomial(n, 1/2) under the model in pages 1–3.

equations.latex: S_{\text{up}} = s\,\exp\left(\mu\,\delta t + \sigma\sqrt{\delta t}\right),\quad S_{\text{down}} = s\,\exp\left(\mu\,\delta t - \sigma\sqrt{\delta t}\right)
equations.meaning: One-step multiplicative update for the stock in the recombining binomial tree: deterministic drift μδt plus a ±σ√δt random component.
equations.intuition: Modeling log-returns over a short interval δt as the sum of a small deterministic drift term and a random shock whose standard deviation scales like √δt, so the multiplicative factor is close to 1 for small δt.

equations.meaning: Number of discrete time steps (ticks) in the interval [0,t].
equations.intuition: As δt → 0, n → ∞ for fixed t, allowing application of limit theorems over many small independent steps.

equations.meaning: Exact expression in the discrete model for the stock value at time t after n steps, expressed in terms of the number X_n of up-jumps.
equations.intuition: Log-price decomposes into deterministic drift μt plus a scaled aggregate noise term: (2X_n-n)/√n behaves like an average of ±1 shocks, multiplied by σ√t gives the cumulative volatility scaling.

equations.meaning: Distributional properties of the number of up-jumps under the symmetric jump probability p=1/2.
equations.intuition: Each step is an independent fair up/down trial; mean and variance scale linearly with n.

equations.meaning: By the Central Limit Theorem, the centered and scaled sum of the ±1 step indicators converges in distribution to a standard normal.
equations.intuition: Many small independent symmetric increments aggregate to Gaussian noise in the continuous limit.

equations.meaning: In the continuous-time limit, the log-price is normally distributed with mean log S_0 + μt and variance σ^2 t, so S_t is log-normal.
equations.intuition: Deterministic accumulation of drift plus Gaussian aggregate noise yields a normal law for log-prices; multiplicative model yields log-normal prices.

figures.description: Title slide 'Overture to continuous models' with bullet points stating motivation: discrete techniques approximate continuous time, discrete model approximates log-normal under P and Q, and can lead to Black–Scholes formula informally.
figures.significance: Sets context and goals for the subsequent modeling: motivate approximation of continuous-time models using a discrete binomial-like framework.

figures.description: Slide 'Model with constant stock growth and noise' listing parameters (δt, σ, μ, r), cash bond formula B_t = exp(r t), one-step update formulas for up/down moves, and statement that p = 1/2.
figures.significance: Specifies the discrete-time multiplicative model structure and parameters that will be analyzed in the small-δt limit.

figures.description: Slide 'Model with constant stock growth and noise, continued' deriving S_t after n = t/δt steps, definition of X_n, binomial mean/variance, and application of CLT to argue log-normal limit.
figures.significance: Shows the derivation connecting the discrete model to the continuous log-normal limit via binomial aggregation and the Central Limit Theorem; central technical slide for the approximation argument.

chunk_summary: Pages 4–6 analyze the discrete-to-continuous approximation under the martingale measure Q and apply it to price a European call. Starting from the discrete recombining tree, the martingale measure probability q for an up-jump is derived (exact formula and small-δt approximation). Under Q the binomial count X_n has mean n q and variance n q(1−q); after normalization (2X_n−n)/√n its distribution converges by the Central Limit Theorem to a normal with mean −√t(μ + 1/2 σ^2 − r)/σ and variance → 1. Consequently S_t is log-normal under Q with log-mean log S0 + (r − 1/2 σ^2) t and variance σ^2 t; equivalently S_t = S0 exp(σ √t Z + (r − 1/2 σ^2) t) with Z ~ N(0,1) under Q. The call price is expressed as the discounted Q-expectation of (S_T − k)+ and evaluated in closed form as the Black–Scholes formula using standard normal CDF Φ.

key_definitions.Q (martingale measure): The risk-neutral probability measure under which discounted asset prices are martingales; expectations under Q are used for pricing.
key_definitions.q (martingale up-jump probability): The risk-neutral probability assigned to an up-step in the discrete tree, computed so that discounted stock is a martingale.
key_definitions.X_n: Number of up-jumps in n discrete ticks (binomial random variable).
key_definitions.S_t under Q (marginal): Stock price at time t under the martingale measure; shown to be log-normal with parameters determined by r and σ.
key_definitions.B_t (cash bond): Riskless bank account process; B_t = exp(r t).
key_definitions.Call option X: European call with maturity T and strike k; payoff X = (S_T − k)+.
key_definitions.\u03a6: Standard normal cumulative distribution function, Φ(x) = Q(Z ≤ x) for Z ~ N(0,1).

theorems.name: Central Limit Theorem (invoked)
theorems.statement: For the binomial count X_n with mean n/2 (or mean n q under Q) and variance proportional to n, the normalized sum (2X_n − n)/√n converges in distribution to a normal random variable as n → ∞ (equivalently δt → 0, n = t/δt → ∞).
theorems.role_in_chunk: Used to justify that the discrete log-returns converge to a normal distribution and hence S_t becomes log-normal in the continuous-time limit, both under P and under the martingale measure Q.

equations.meaning: Exact expression for the risk-neutral up-step probability q in a one-step discrete tree ensuring the discounted stock is a martingale.
equations.intuition: Choose q so the expected next-step stock price, discounted at the risk-free rate, equals the current price (martingale condition).

equations.meaning: Small-δt approximation of the martingale probability q in terms of model parameters μ, σ, r.
equations.intuition: When time-steps are small, q is near 1/2 with a correction proportional to √{δt} driven by the difference between real drift μ (plus volatility correction) and the risk-free rate r.

equations.meaning: Limit mean and variance of the normalized up-count under Q (with n = t/δt).
equations.intuition: The normalization converts the binomial fluctuation to a Gaussian with a deterministic shift depending on the drift mismatch; variance tends to 1 by binomial scaling.

equations.meaning: Marginal distribution of S_t under the martingale measure Q: log-normal with mean parameter (r − 1/2 σ^2) t and variance σ^2 t.
equations.intuition: Under risk-neutral valuation, the drift in log-price is r − 1/2 σ^2 so that discounted stock is a martingale; randomness comes from σ√t Z.

equations.latex: V_0 = E_Q\left[B_T^{-1}\,(S_T - k)^+\right] = E_Q\left[\left(S_0\exp\left(\sigma\sqrt{T}Z - \tfrac{1}{2}\sigma^2 T\right) - k e^{-rT}\right)^+\right]
equations.meaning: Price at time 0 of a European call computed as the discounted Q-expectation of its payoff.
equations.intuition: Under Q, price is present value of expected payoff; substituting S_T's log-normal form converts pricing to an expectation over a normal variable Z.

equations.meaning: Black–Scholes closed-form expression for the European call price using the standard normal CDF Φ.
equations.intuition: The expectation over truncated log-normal payoff can be evaluated by change of variables to normal Z, yielding two Φ-terms representing probabilities/weights for the option being in-the-money adjusted by discounting.

figures.description: Slide titled 'Under the martingale measure' displaying the exact martingale-probability formula for q and its small-δt approximation, plus the statement that X_n is binomial with mean n q and variance n q(1−q).
figures.significance: Introduces the risk-neutral probability q and shows how the discrete model's jump probabilities are adjusted under Q; sets up the distributional calculations required to pass to the continuous limit.

figures.description: Continuation slide 'Under the martingale measure, continued' which states the mean and asymptotic variance of (2X_n−n)/√n, invokes the Central Limit Theorem, and gives the log-normal expression for S_t under Q: S_t = S_0 exp(σ√t Z + (r − 1/2 σ^2) t).
figures.significance: Concludes the limiting distribution under Q, showing that the discrete model converges to the geometric Brownian motion marginal used in Black–Scholes pricing.

figures.description: Slide 'Pricing a call option' that defines the call payoff X = (S_T − k)+, writes the pricing expectation under Q, and states the resulting Black–Scholes formula with normal CDF Φ.
figures.significance: Connects the derived log-normal law under Q to option valuation and presents the closed-form Black–Scholes price expression.
